description:
Plasmodium reichenowi is a species of malaria parasite that infects chimpanzees. It is closely related to Plasmodium falciparum, the most deadly form of malaria that infects humans.

Plasmodium reichenowi is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Plasmodium. It has a complex life cycle that involves both a vertebrate host (the chimpanzee) and an invertebrate host (the Anopheles mosquito). The parasite's life cycle begins when an infected mosquito injects sporozoites into the chimpanzee's bloodstream during a blood meal. These sporozoites then travel to the liver, where they multiply and develop into merozoites. The merozoites then enter the chimpanzee's red blood cells, where they continue to replicate and eventually rupture the cells, releasing more merozoites to infect more red blood cells.

Plasmodium reichenowi is endemic to central Africa, where it is found in wild chimpanzee populations. It is believed to have co-evolved with its chimpanzee host over millions of years, and it is often used as a model organism for studying the evolutionary history and genetic diversity of malaria parasites.

While Plasmodium reichenowi is not known to infect humans, its close relationship to Plasmodium falciparum provides insights into the evolution and biology of human malaria, which remains a major global health problem.
